Granada's Foreign Gambit - July to October 1431


July: The Embassy Departs


Within days of Málaga's fall, Sultan Yusuf III dispatches his most persuasive diplomat—the same Abu Abdullah al-Zaghal who came to Seville last year—accompanied by religious scholars and bearing desperate letters. They sail from a minor port Granada still controls, racing across the Strait to Ceuta and then overland to the Marinid court at Fez.


The message is stark: The last Muslim kingdom in Al-Andalus faces extinction. Christian crusaders take our cities. Without aid, Granada falls by next summer.


August: Fez Deliberates


The Marinid Sultan Abd al-Haqq II is only seventeen and weak, surrounded by regents and powerful viziers with competing interests. The council debates for weeks:


Against intervention: Morocco has internal troubles. Portugal threatens their northern borders. Castile's navy dominates the strait. Granada has asked for help before and wasted it.


For intervention: Religious duty demands response to crusade. If Granada falls, Portugal and Castile turn on Morocco next. Pan-Islamic credibility at stake. Granada's gold and desperate promises are attractive.


The Compromise (Late August): Morocco commits to a modest expeditionary force—enough to show solidarity, not enough to bankrupt themselves or invite Portuguese retaliation. They promise 2,500 troops (mix of regular soldiers and tribal volunteers) with experienced commanders, to arrive by November when weather permits crossing. Immediate financial aid: 120,000 gold dinars sent by fast galley, arriving Granada in early September.


September: Money Arrives, Hope Rises


The Moroccan gold reaches Granada in early September. Sultan Yusuf uses it immediately:


Pays overdue wages to garrison troops (preventing mutinies)

Purchases emergency grain supplies from remaining trade partners

Hires mercenaries from the city's desperate refugees

Bribes wavering commanders to stay loyal

Begins modest fortification improvements around capital


Granada's morale lifts marginally. The Sultan has done something. Proof that the Muslim world hasn't abandoned them. Rumors spread through the markets: "Moroccan armies are coming. Thousands of warriors. The tide will turn."


Reality is less impressive, but hope is a currency in desperate times.


October: Reinforcements En Route


By October, Morocco begins assembling the promised force at Ceuta. Weather and logistics delay them—November crossing is realistic, perhaps late October if conditions permit. The troops are adequate: some veteran infantry, tribal cavalry, religious volunteers inspired by jihad rhetoric. Not elite, but not worthless either. Led by an experienced Moroccan commander, Qaid Ali ibn Rashid.


Granada prepares to receive them. The Sultan plans to integrate them into capital defenses and perhaps send raiding forces to harass Castilian positions through winter.
